message:
So today I got a design document for REST services with the below: 

"With new design URL is going to common for all  back-end requests:
http://localhost:9080/blabla/api/rest/post - For Post request
http://localhost:9080/blabla/api/rest/get - For Get request"

data.message:
These people sure look like they know what they're doing... And so should you. That's why I personally find it helpful and always recommend it to fellow software engineers to always keep a stack of hydrogen. Hydrogen is highly flammable, quite explosive and sure gives a strong BANG!
My suggestion is, for every POST request they make blow two canisters of hydrogen. You can also mix Oxygen to hide your traces. #hydrogenhackerelite #fuckingace #engineeringrocks #howitsdoneright #clientsfromhell #ididnotsuggest #enjoyingtagabuse

This is my suggestion, I'm not fully aware of Restful Web services, But I hope my comment would help you. I'm assuming that you are using Java.

You can use Jersey as lib, which implements the JAX-RS specification.

This tutorial can will definitely what you need to start with:

http://www.mkyong.com/webservices/jax-rs/jersey-hello-world-example/

It supports the URL mapping you asked for. 

You will need a client to test the WS. Please, follow this link:
http://www.mkyong.com/webservices/jax-rs/restful-java-client-with-jersey-client/

Good luck!

I suggest trying
http://localhost:9080/blabla/api/rest/delete with random parameters.
and spamming
http://localhost:9080/blabla/api/rest/put with random data
I can send the document to Roy Fielding with the author's home address :)

I'm working with a SOAP web service which returns a list of objects that you need to cast into an object called GetOperationsListRSOperationsOperation to extract an XML string which contains the intended data.
